content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-024-16-A |Item_parent=Main complications of pregnancy. |Item_parent_short=Main complications of pregnancy. |Rank=A |Title=Knowing prevention in subsequent pregnancies |Description=None |Rubric=Management |Contributors=Paul Berveiller,Philippe Deruelle |Order=16}} There is a risk of recurrence if the patient has a history of pregnancy-induced hypertension in a similar or different way (vascular-placental pathologies = pre-eclampsia, IUGR, HRP, MFIU) in around 1 in 5 patients. You will need : - any "preconception consultation" (to adapt antihypertensive treatment, check that there are no contraindications and organise coordinated follow-up) +/- direct follow-up in a suitable maternity unit - stop smoking'' etc... [[Prevention of tobacco-related risks SD-314]] - preventive treatment with low-dose aspirin: 75 to 160 mg/d in the evening before 16 and up to 35 weeks' gestation (only in cases of a history of severe IUGR or early and/or severe pre-eclampsia with induced preterm birth). properties.question: What is the recommended treatment for a patient with a history of pregnancy-induced hypertension?
properties.option_a: Stop smoking and take low-dose aspirin for the entire pregnancy.
properties.option_b: Preventive treatment with low-dose aspirin: 75 to 160 mg/d in the morning and up to 35 weeks' gestation.
properties.option_c: Preventive treatment with low-dose aspirin: 75 to 160 mg/d in the evening before 16 and up to 35 weeks' gestation.
properties.option_d: Preventive treatment with low-dose aspirin: 75 to 160 mg/d in the morning and up to 35 weeks' gestation (only in cases of a history of severe IUGR or early and/or severe pre-eclampsia with induced preterm birth).
